text: I own both a t420 and t430, along with it's dock. But I still find my Latitude e6430 a vastly superior as is my e7470. But for a guy who had a 600 series Thinkpad as his prized possession in high school, and trust me mid 1998 it was something, my t420 brings back fond and uber cool memories and then some. But what bothers me isn't just the price. The t series line was never a cheap business series. The amount of bloat that came with my t420 out of the box was frightening. Even the bing bar was installed! For some of you that fix might be to upgrade to Windows 10, that's fine. I usually run Mint Linux, so I get it. But choices aside for a business class computer in that price range, you would expect better. Yet, anyone who has had to deal with ThinkVantage, or finding a set of restore disks (because you can't simply download a Windows imagine from Lenovo until recently) knows finding the disks is just the start. As a bonus, you can avoid the bloat by using only the first disk and installing the drivers after the fact. But that defeats the purpose if you ask me of easily setting up these types of computers and when your doing 100s, thats a lot of time. My guess is this is probably why we now see mostly Dell in enterprise. Not even HP can easily compete with what Dell has in that area. But most people who love these Thinkpads have long lost all this stuff to start with or are willing to put up with the troubles to own a 2nd to none laptop. Not that I would personally recommend anything past the t430 with it's chiclet keyboard. But early Tpads, while kind of a niche, It's defenders are loyal and there's lots of good reasons to defend.

text: Put Arch Linux on this thing and you have my next laptop upgrade. :) Better than my old Dell Latitude E6410 am I right? It's nice to see there being another laptop made that has an actual keyboard on it. I cannot type on these crappy "Ultra thing" laptops these days because the keyboard doesn't feel right to me at all. You cannot type on that thing and then type on my laptop then easily want to go back to typing on a MacBook or something. It does not feel right. The keyboard on these things are great. The only thing I have to say about this. The display? Terrible, CPU? Terrible. RAM, 4GB of DDR3 is not enough for me. Hard drive? Well a 3100 rpm laptop hard drive from 2010 does not age well lets just say that. Yes, a lot of this stuff I can just upgrade for myself but just to future proof this thing would cost me as much to just buy a new laptop. OH I FORGOT THE 2 INCH TOUCHPAD! With complimentary top and bottom buttons, that are half the size of the touchpad itself. I have a mouse for this. It's that bad. I choose to sit on my couch with a mouse hooked up, beside me on the cushion. But then the viewing angles on this laptop holy shit it is the worst. I can't even look at this laptop head on, at a perfect angle without seeing discoloration. That's right. If I was looking at the display at a perfect angle, no matter what I would see black somewhere on the display. Displays really came a long way. Compared to my phone there is no single color that looks the same. Colors don't even look like that color and I have a Google Pixel 2 XL so that is really setting the bar. (SARCASM BIO"ADVERTISER FRIENDLY CONTENT") Compared to my Pixel 2 XL, which the reviews for this phone's display was terrible. The colors were the worst part about it, everything looked drab and nothing was right, compare that to my laptop I mean oh my god. If you pay me for the shipping to send this laptop over to you guys you can see for yourselves Linus. Put it on your videos or something and slap a LTT sticker on the back of it and send it back. Or keep it, just make sure that I have a Raspberry Pi 3 Plus cluster at the very least. Because I really do not need to spend all that money on a new laptop which I should buy me a gaming PC not a laptop but I need to be able to do my school work on it, at school. Last time I checked desktop's were not very portable. I'd take that hulking monstrosity that has that 5GHz Core i9 off your hands. I'll gladly trade you for that. But I would not take that piece of trash Core i9 MacBook Pro. I know that you guys don't even want that and I don't either. I compile a lot of software on my laptop. I don't need my laptop to be 240 F or 100C before the fan even turns on. What would even be the point of having a Macbook if you were going to put Linux on that? Not like that they have better performance or anything over the other laptops that you could get for cheaper. How much are these 2017 Think pads? Next time they come out with one I might just buy me one. If it has the keyboard. If it doesn't that's a no deal.

author: Mike

text: So I am not as old as Linus (not saying he is old, saying he is older than me lol) as I am only 18, BUT when I was little I loved computers and even gaming on them, but my family was pretty broke most my life, my dad did have some older stuff laying around though. My first laptop was a Dell Lattitude CP, it had a 233MHZ Pentium 2 processor, 64MB of ram and a 5GB HDD with Windows 98SE. Now I don't remember what graphics it had, but I know it didn't have almost any 3D support. This laptop is what got me into gaming though as I found two old game discs in one of my dad's old boxes, Earthsiege 2, and Need For Speed 2, I managed to get them both running and played those for hours upon hours. Now this was back in about 2007, later I got upgraded to my dads old Dell Lattitude C810, with a 1.13GHZ Pentium 3, a GeForce 440GO with 32MB of VRAM, a 20GB hard drive, 256MB of RAM, and Windows 2000, with 98 installed as well, it also had a 15 inch 1600x1200 display I think, I know it was high for its time. I played so many old games on that such as the previous two games, Jetfighter 4, the old Star Wars Battlefront series and many more. I could even run Star Wars Empire At War on it, low settings of course but with playable framerates. The IBM Thinkpad was a good laptop, and one thing they beat Dell on was their cases, we had one just a bit newer than that 560 and me and my siblings dropped that thing so many times and it never cracked. But Dell definitely had better laptops in other aspects, their trackpads were actually pretty good, and those nipple things just plain suck, I would take even some of the worst trackpads over one of those crappy things, they were just plain crap. But Dell had the better laptops in terms of performance, reliability (except the cases were easier to crack) and usability as Dell supported many operating systems on those and you can still get those drivers from them today! I think it would be awesome to see a video comparing an old Dell Inspiron 8200 laptop to a modern one, just for old times sake. Heck I still have one if yall want it lol.

text: Ahhh, Thinkpads, I have fond and somewhat bittersweet memories of the Thinkpad 560e. Back in the early 2000's, my mother was ill with terminal cancer. We bought her a cheap 560e from a used computer place, and she instantly fell in love with it. It went with her everywhere, hospital, the hospice. It was so rugged, and almost indestructible. She used it with MSN Messenger to keep in touch with her sister. Thats all she used it for, but for her, it was a lifeline. Sadly the laptop expired soon after she did, and I was unable to repair it. Otherwise I'd probably still have it just for the memories.

text:
I owned and sold multiple IBM think pads back in the day! 
Part of me would love to own this. 

But it's rather expensive and if it's actually limited production I won't find one cheap in 3 years.... 

But for as often as I use my laptop. My old Dell Precision M6500 will do me for years to come yet. 
The first Gen I5 still doing good for me! 
8gb of ram is enough. 
I have both an SSD and HDD in a laptop! 
It's dedicated GPU is old but hell I can play Mortal Kombat X on it decently! 
Also rocks a 17inch screen! 

Yes it's heavy. I'm lucky to get 2 and a half hours Web browsing let alone anything else. 
But I'm still very happy! 

And it also has a nubby thing!

We had an IBM Thinkpad in the eary 2000's and I recall it being quite a good little laptop. I never used it much, since it was my dad's notebook, but once in a while I'd use it to play games like Warcraft II and GTA II, which simply wouldn't run on our other laptop. text:
they put a shithouse GPU and CPU in it for one reason only

if they included a quad core CPU and a GTX 900 series or 10 series, it would become the perfect all rounder 
good specs 
durability 
long battery life 
HOT SWAPPABLE battery (you can change batteries while powered on) 
great cooling 
nostalgia 

there would be no reason to buy their other devices as this one would be great for everyone from businesses to gamers
 
as a gamer i can tell you that theres nothing worse than being stuck with a dead battery and no way to charge it, but with a removable battery i can swap the dead one for a charged one and continue gaming (and since its hot swappable i wont even need to turn it off to do so) 

i think they dont want average consumers having a computer with genuinely useful features (like removable batteries) because it will eat into their profits (since people will replace the dying battery instead of the whole computer) 
but they still want businesses to have those features, and whats the easiest way to do that? release a computer with a high price tag and rubbish specs

businesses will buy it for the usability but consumers wont touch it because the specs are barely as good as a netbook from 2010

text: I work for a charity supporting disabled computer users and the IBM trackpoint pointing device has proved to be an actual requirement for anyone doing art work (including a lady who does paperback book covers commercially). For the first week you want to throw it out the window but after a month you wouldn't want to use a mouse. They persuaded me to adopt it. I use an old T60p for productive work because I find the reduced font size on the new reduced height screens a total pain ('widescreen' when its the same width as the old full height type? there is a word for that!). I do have a couple of more recent Thinkpads but the cramped screens mean they sit on the network and have processor intensive jobs or printer work farmed out to them. Levono do seem to be moving back toward quality so I will continue to buy them, but I wish they did a separate keyboard with a track point on it that I could use with a tablet in portrait mode for editing manuals.

text:
Now for them to make a 26th annivarsary edition with a few key improvements:
-3:2 display with decent colour accuracy (Microsoft has some sweet 13.5" ones that should be a good fit)
-Either ~8550u+MX150 or Ryzen 7 2700U (or a balls-to-the-wall version with the new Intel+AMD chips at 65W)

Otherwise, this is pretty much perfect. Perfect keyboard, a trackpoint (yes, for precision and choice) brilliant hot-swap battery function, great I/O, great design. If they made those upgrades, kept it at the same weight, I'd gladly pay whatever they wanted for it.

author: Finian Blackett

text:
@Old Liquid This is build quality. The reason its so thick and heavy is because these things come with pressed steel frames. They hide the HDD/SSD/mobo in there, so there is less internal space and thermal headroom for expensive components. However, That'll save your bacon if you drop it, and you can easily replace the external plastic parts. The keyboard deck flex is because of the low set keyboard, which has nearly desktop keyboard travel distances. 

If you know anything about cars, Its like a body-on-frame construction vs. a monocoque.

text:
"This episode was brought to you by TunnelBear" - yeah well I'm fairly sure that this episode was brought to us by Lenovo. Because there's just no way Linus would've actually told us to buy this thing. 1900$ bucks for these specs? You can buy an older T420 for under 200$, throw in SSD and it's basically the same thing (maybe throw in i7-2670QM as well and you're basically on the same level with this shite, and you're still under 400$)

Lenovo just had bunch of 940MX's in the warehouse and thought "fuck it, people have boner for the retro thinkpad, they'll eat anything we throw at them". Like seriously give me one (1!) good reason why not go for MX150 instead which has same power consumption but is 50% more powerful. And why the fuck not quad core 8th gen Intels? Lenovo was already using them on IdeaPads and Yogas long before Retro was introduced. 

Their target consumers are - as Hart Henry mentioned - the oldschool guys who just don't care how much it costs and what it does as long as it's advertised as the "good ole' Thinkpad with """"""""modern""""""""" specs"

But I really hate the fact that Linus is actually advertising it as a good sell to regular people. For me it's striking obvious that he sold his ass to Lenovo.

Also btw. this has nothing to do with IBM, Lenovo just added the colorful logo because people requested it... I mean most people requested the 16:10 screen but it would drastically increase the pricetag since they'd have to get them custom made... Such laptop would have to cost, like, 1900$ or so.

text: We have systems with i5 6500T, these are desktop processors that regularly run at sub 1 watt power draw, in fact, while browsing the web, my tablets has a core m5-6y57, but they both are within 0.5 watts of each other, one has 4 cores, one only 2, one has a TDP of 5, one has a TDP of 35. It is true that the VRMs and chipset to support the higher powered processor will use more power, but the(modern) processors themselves only uses that extra power if you need it. Making the old adage apply much better to computers 'Better to have it and not need it, than need it and not have it'. right around the 4th gen is where speed step really started to improve the power draw when at idle. EXAMPLE my pair of X5690s(released in 2011) will idle at 40 watts each, at work the next generation E5 2680, with the same 130 watt TDP will idle at 37 watts but has 2 more cores(all power draw according to HWMonitor+ and TDP from ark intel com)

they put a shithouse GPU and CPU in it for one reason only 

if they included a quad core CPU and a GTX 900 series or 10 series it would become the perfect all rounder

nostalgia

but with a removable battery i can swap the dead one for a charged one and continue gaming (and since its hot swappable i wont even need to turn it off to do so) 

i think they dont want average consumers having a computer with genuinely useful features (like removable batteries) because it will eat into their profits (since people will replace the dying battery instead of the whole computer)

release a computer with a high price tag and rubbish specs 
businesses will buy it for the usability but consumers wont touch it because it cant do anything intensive
author: MWB Gaming

text:
+Edward Wood, good luck carrying that thing around! Also, Thinkpads are expensive, even people buying Thinkpads say they are expensive, but if you have ever been in an office you knew why. It's hard to find a notebook built like a Thinkpad. 

They aren't made out of a single block of fancy aluminum or with cheap plastic parts, they are built with an internal metal frame that keeps the electronics protected even when dropping the laptop, and the external case is made out of magnesium or titanium (or both) depending on the particular series.

The keyboard is spill-resistant and easy to clean. The internals are easily serviceable.

text: The new thinkpad takes everything that made the thinkpad great and tosses it out the window. Thinkpad themselves admit this, the next will return some of the features that made thinkpad great. The trackpad and nipple ergonomics where completely ruined for example. Impossible to not hit the trackpad with your palm if you use the nipple, this is made even worse by not having hard buttons which results in right clicking everything you don't want to. I legitimately get more work done on my old thinkpad than the new one because of the lack of life quality features from old thinkpads. Small details like lack of dedicated multimedia keys, odd laptopesque keyboard layout (unlike the desktop keyboard layout of older thinkpads), bad trackpad position in relation to the nipple, the battery which can no longer be used as a grip while standing (something that was a godsend for me in my workshop), the lack of physical mouse buttons which causes frequent misclicking, and finally the shabby build quality, which to be fair is good by today's standards but doesn't feel like a machine that will survive the tough environment i work in. Safe to say i will be selling my 2017 thinkpad and keeping the older one, using desktop for heavier work.

text: Do you want to know if it'll be here in 20 years? Simple: On top of having good build quality, are the storage, RAM, and battery all replaceable? Is it easy to take apart and thoughtfully laid out? Does it have the old-fashioned IBM standard magnesium roll-cage? Does it have a spill-resistant keyboard? Will replacement parts be easily obtainable online? These are all part of why those laptops are still kicking around. I'm sure this thing is nice on the outside, but in this case it's the inside that counts. Making it a limited edition already spells doom for the future availability of parts, assuming it's not all soldered and glued together like most new laptops.

text: The only issue I have with Lenovo is their support. The laptops are great to use but when something goes wrong with the hardware and it's under warranty, Lenovo are very difficult to work with (at least in the UK). They have recently also started using IBM engineers again, but it usually takes several missed appointments for them to uphold an onsite warranty service request. So if you can afford it and are happy waiting a while for support should something go wrong (we waited over 2 months for one client, and around 15-20 phone calls), they are great machines otherwise.

text: Honestly in a few years like most laptop's built the Thinkpad will be obsolete and you'll have to fork out another grand or two for a new one. My company use to use Thinkpad's a for about a decade or more as our mainstream system support and for those who need portable computers within our enterprise. As a whole Lenovo  has dominated the corporate enterprise due to its large volume and supply chain. In the last few years we moved on from Lenovo and started using Gigabyte and in the near future will be rolling out Razer due to the specs and power of these laptops. Thinkpad's offer none of these features in their laptops and our cost savings have out weigh the initial roll out over half a year.

author: Charger Sheen

text:
For all the Louis Rossman / retro thinkpad bitching fans: 

People are angry because Lenovo marketed this as 'retro' which they shouldn't have. This is a modern laptop with a different keyboard. its not retro in any way. Don't think about it as a retro laptop and then maybe there's not so much to get angry about. Remember - Lenovo didn't have to do this. Its a one off. 4:3 display is impossible to source. lid is too thin for the ThinkLight. they reused existing motherboard due to it being a one off model. The only 14" laptop with a more powerful CPU is the heavier T470p. And that has the same GPU as the TP25. There is no 14" business laptop with a better GPU at the moment. (no XPS is not a business laptop, look at the Latitude line). And when has the Thinkpad had a great screen? Go look at your venerated T61 again and tell me again look past the 4:3 aspect ratio and thats when you realize its a crappy TFT screen with CCFL backlighting. Also this is not advertised as a workstation (a la the P series). Lets look at the specs again, now compare the ports keyboard removable battery and wwan options to other similarly priced notebooks like the Macbook Pro with the stupid gimmicky touch bar and no ports and a shit keyboard or the MS Surfacebook 2 which costs $500 more and tell me again how this is overpriced.

text:
This was at best a poor review and at worst shilling. The egrigous keyboard flex seen at 2:06 goes completely unmentioned despite being the first criteria used to evaluate almost any laptop. Build quality comparisons like rigidity, drop tests and paint wear is completely absent. The unique Thinklight existed on X230 but was omitted on this model?

Joking about missing sliders, but overlooking the fact that Lenovo Thinkpads dropped the dedicated, hardware-implemented volume and brightness controls that IBM had?

But I guess all effort went into the stylish intro. Style over substance, the very opposite of what Thinkpads used to represent.

text: I love my ThinkPad W530. 24 gigs of ram, 1.5 TB of SSD storage, I7 3940XM, 2GB K2000M, FHD screen. I'm not a long time ThinkPad user, in fact this W530 is my first, however, I didn't pay an arm and a leg for it because I pretty much built it myself, I fix laptops as a hobby. I bought 3940XM/K2000M w530 for parts with no ram and broken screen, used 4 DDR3 sodimms I had in storage from other laptops I salvaged, bought a replacement lid, LCD panel, and bezel, and rebuilt it. After buying all the convenience cards (wifi card, bluetooth module, etc.) it only cost me around $600. The Msata SSD was probably the single most expensive part in the entire build save the computer itself. I can see why people would pay so much for such a quality machine.

text:
The second-hand Thinkpads are amazing, the build quality is really good and I used to use a MacBook Pro. Bought my ThinkPad T440s on eBay broken for $170, fixed it for $30, and replaced the screen with 1080p for $40. Added my own SSD and competes with my gaming pc in terms of responsiveness. Fixing these are easy and many parts are replaceable (replaced the touchpad with the version that has buttons). Battery(s) lasts 5-10 hours which blew my mind because most laptops I owned only lasted 2-5 hours. I use it more than my $1400 gaming pc nowadays, glad the Thinkpad brand is still alive and kicking.

Oh and don't get me started on the docking stations, may seem dumb, but when you got to run out the door all it takes is one button, and you don't have to worry about working with cables every time you want to set it up as a desktop. All I need now is a 4k IPS DisplayPort screen...

text:
Who originally made the thinkpad, IBM. What was the thinkpad used for/in? IT (hence the ports, robust-ability, expand-ability), even the shelf in a mainframe is made for a thinkpad ffs! The thinkpad (with its 2 mouses etc) is designed for the IT professional. The Mac, designed for old people (I worked for Apple retail, our target market was old people hence the classes in store) with expendable incomes.

I hear you about the use of Macs in design, although more of a statement then necessity (see LMG, no Macs). College, not really. Work, define? Tbh all you have said for the Mac is if you have money to burn like a design company, a student or a profitable company then you'll use one, but not ever need one. Plus most of these companies use these Macs for many years, you still see late 2009 27" macs in design scenarios. Again status symbol, if you don't provide an office full of macs your not going to get any talented designers. Proves how stupid your argument is.
Soldered 8GB ram, built in battery, CPU throttling with NO cooling, limited software and no ports. ¬£2000. Sold to the idiot with too much cash to wave about ;) Even then new iMac has a proprietary CPU socket ffs! (you can upgrade the CPU in the thinkpad).
This video is about a ThinkPad, not a mac, or a mac wannabe. A ThinkPad. They make that very clear in the video. IT professionals and business people, not designers with coke under their noses, or housewives in Starbucks. Professionals. Simple.

Not sure where these Apple fanboys came from but a Mac and a ThinkPad are about as similar or relevant as the Switch and a ThinkPad. Totally different use case and product. So my argument still stands and is correct :)
author: tomtalk24

text:
Do not be fooled by looks. Thinkpads is built magnesium alloy roll cage underneath its plastic cover. So it looks weak, but in fact it is tough. Macbooks look tough due to the metal casing, but it is actually weak since the metal is so thin and it has no other protection.

Watch some vids of drop tests thinkpads endure, which no macbook would even survive.
author: David HY. Jeong

text:
tomtalk24: I'm sorry, but your grounds for an argument are completely incorrect and ill-informed. I'm not discounting the capability of a ThinkPad in an IT environment, but to dismiss Apple computers to elderly citizens and idiots with too much money is absolutely absurd.

Working in a creative industry, both in photography and audio production, I can tell you that one of the main highlights of Apple products is standardization. This may seem like a drawback to the power-lusting, IO-crazed average pc user, but is one of the main selling features of Apple computers. 

If you'll take a look at the industry standard audio production software, Avid Pro Tools, you'll notice they have amazing Apple support and terrible PC support (within a guideline). This is because while there are thousands of configurations of PCs that come out a year, there are a very limited number of variations for a mac. This makes it easier to design software that runs its best within a tailored environment. Many software companies in creative industries work this way because it's the most efficient way to function. 

I can also tell you from personal use, I'm still using a 2008 MacBook, and a 2009 Mac Pro to handle all my session work. Why? Because it simply just works still. I've had no reason to upgrade because all my software (that is all within the last 2 years of development updates) continues to function just fine for my needs. When I update one day, I'll be buying a mac again because they simply function for what I need. Much of the creative industry works like this.
author: Zack Murray

text:
Zack Murray food for thought. Next time you're in an apple store, observe the demagraphic. Take a look at the workgroup tables. We had inside jokes for running them. It's the disposable income effect, those who can spend 2k on a laptop with 2ghz cpus and little ram, those who need no more than a mid range mobile gpu... For 2k! Fararri isn't exclusive to old people, but that's where the money is and in apples case, that's where the lack of knowledge is. They buy an apple for the experience.
Not saying only old people use apple, but what sain person buys a computer with that low level of specs for that price? Apple is a marketing company and that's all.

author: Quackyrole

text:
What most people don't know is that, even dating back as far as to the very first model, "ThinkPad" had always been a completely "Made in Japan" line of computers. The task was mostly assigned to IBM's Yamato Development Laboratory (Yokohama), from its initial concept, design, development, all the way to the actual manufacturing. 
Don't believe it? Well, look it up. 
Back in the early 2010s' Lenovo tried to move the ThinkPad division to China to take over the development, but soon gave up. 
So now, as far as I am aware of, Lenovo's ThinkPad division is moved back to Yokohama into the hands of the Japanese engineers who has the knowledge and experience to handle the task.

text: I own a Lenovo ThinkPad carbon X1 rev3, and I have to say I like it better than the anniversary edition. it has the pointing stick, great battery, great glass touchpad, great 144p IPS touchscreen, and an awesome build quality I have not seen on any other laptop. oh, and also it has more than enough IO and it's actually feasible to put in a backpack. i have to say, as someone who didn't own a pointing stick enabled laptop before this, i prefer it over the touchpad 100% of the time, as i find it as intuitive as a mouse. the only thing i use the touchpad for are multifinger gestures, like zooming and scrolling.

text:
5:49 "Because for us, the anniversary edition ended up being all about options". Those not being hardware options. 
There is NOTHING you can configure on this laptop when ordering, hardware wise. Wasn't the point of Thinkpads of old that you could choose between multiple processors, displays, memory, GPU and storage to make it suit your need? 

If you wanted you could get a higher tier display, but not here. "14.0" FHD PPS AntiGlare Multitouch LED (1920x1080) with integrated camera" is all you get. No option for higher resolution for god sake.

Or maybe offer a quad core processor? Nah, "7th Generation Intel¬Æ Core‚Ñ¢ i7-7500U Processor (2.70GHz 4MB)" is all you get. But I would pay more for quad core? Well too bad, dual core is all you get, now stop whining, we know what you want.

Louis Rossman has a great video on the Thinkpad Retro from his perspective on being a Thinkpad poweruser over long time.
https://youtu.be/UxQGhqF60zE <-- link to his video.

The new retro is only made to appeal to the nostalgic feel of the good old Thinkpads... What a cash-grab...

text: It all depends on how much you will pay for either of these laptops, I do have a Lenovo Ideapad i3 processor, it gets the job done but isn't optimized to handle Adobe products such as Photoshop, AfterEffects or Adobe Premiere, but you can still use it tho. I'd probably recommend a laptop with some GPU if video editing is what you need. I also have a Dell Inspiron 15 i5 processor (about 2 years older) and still it is a beast, even though it doesn't have any graphics card, it runs smoothly any Adobe product. So like I said, Lenovo Laptops are pretty solid, but your choice might depend on how much you are willing to spend.
author: Bryan Mario

text: Oh and I forgot to tell you; if you still want a Lenovo laptop, you can't go wrong with the Thinkpad, but Core i5 processors or i7 are the ones you should be looking at for video editing purposes, avoid i3 or AMD processors. I hope I answered your question.

text: Well, the short Answer would just be: "No". The more detailed and  sightly longer one: Video editing needs power with a core i7, in the best case a not that bad dedicated GPU and in additional a lot of RAM (the more the better - 8 GB are enough but I prefer 16).  I would consider everything with the power of a GTX 670 or better suitable. If you are used to MacOS and Finalcut you can go for something like that, If you prefer windows and the Adobe Suit like I personally do, you should go for something that is a bit gamer because this machines usually have some acceptable GPU and enough RAM. I use a some years old MSI Laptop with a GTX970M, 16GB and an I7 47XX (don't remember the exact model) as to go device for Video editing and Photoshop and would recommend to use something like this.

text: Thinkpads as old as the T60, and T61 (plus the X-line, R-line, etc. Core 2 duo models) are still usable as work boxes if you upgrade the ram and give it a nice SSD. These things are dirt cheap on ebay and are very easy to disassemble and work on as well as get parts for. I picked up a T510 (i5 unit) for $50 that had a locked bios. I unlocked the bios, dropped in a SSD and ram upgrade and it's one of the fastest laptops i've ever used. The only downside is you have to find your own drivers if you're running win10.

author: Ryan Zijun Meng

text: I have to say, the paper specification has disappointed me with this. I adore Thinkpads and I have retained some of my older machines simply down to how good they are. I feel for the target market, they missed some tricks here. For one thing, 16:9 screen is a big let down. I believe that most people going for this would have preferred a 16:10 display as it is just so much better when dealing with productivity tasks. Likewise, a quad core CPU really is a must. I would prefer to lose the GPU and have a good quad core instead, as a business laptop is going to make much better use of that. With all that being said, if the price were lower, I would want something like this. I miss the old keyboard a lot, so i hope they give this niche market another go sometime.

text: Definitely agree that the price is on the high side, but probably not as much as other people think. A lot of business class laptops like the HP Elitebook 820 and 840 with an I7 and other configurations range from $1250 to $1700 depending on configuration. For example my company just bought a batch of HP Elitebook 840 G4's with 512 GB SSD, I7 processor, 1440p screen (no touchscreen), and 16 GB of RAM for about $1700. Add extra warranty services and it comes out to about $1900. The 840 is probably a little bit nicer due to the higher resolution screen, but know that it is fairly common practice currently for business class laptops to charge a high premium compared to consumer laptops. A lot of coworkers are very surprised when I tell them that the 840 and 820 still run dual cores, but that's the norm until the 8th gen intel processors.

author: KingMysion

text:
I have no idea how "rugged" the early thinkpads 10 years ago were, but I am sure that in recent years, thinkpads are more of a scam, even for business users. Any other laptop can do the same things a thinkpad can (except of the red nipple ofc, but given how good trackpads are nowadays, the nipple is more of a gimmick than a useful feature). My friend and I bought a lenovo laptop almost at the same time, while I got a deal for a thinkpad, my friend got a deal for an ideapad. The non-discounted price is identical for both model and configuration we bought, except his was an i7 quad core and mine is an i5 dual core. (my model has an i7 version, but without the discrete gpu, ofc at higher price) Both of our laptops are big 15in models, exact same specs other than the cpu, but his came in a partial metal body and was lighter while mine was entirely plastic and came with horrible downward firing speakers. As for ruggedness, I do not see reason either. The most vulnerable part, being the hdd is just a standard mounting mechanism and no harware redundancy as the features came in all as the included bloatware. It is just a scam because you are paying for a worse laptop and getting bloatware in return.

Nowadays, hdds are often opted out of laptops, which make vibration and drops a non-issue in data integrity. The lighter weight also helps in reducing impulse suffered by the laptop, which proves the thinkpad lineup is redundant for the mainstream. In fact I think the lower end offerings in the thinkpad line up ruins the thinkpad branding on the extreme high end where every tiny bit of extra durability is absolutely needed.

author: dogboy0912

text: No touchpad buttons. The last good ThinkPad models were still the "3" series - T430, T430s, T530, W530. I'm stunned by how few people mention this absolutely unforgivable, deal-breaking oversight. I'm sorry, but I just can't use clickpads - that travesty that Apple unleased upon the world by copycat designs. Touchpads need buttons. Thumb rests in the lower-left edge of the pad, ready to click things. Tapping is good for silent clicks (but even the Thinkpads had soft-click buttons), but beyond that? Clickpads are absolutely awful. As you go for a click, the action of pressing harder on the pad usually moves the cursor as well. Having my thumb resting on that corner of the pad almost always causes problems (as it drifts up and down, on and off the click area, it causes unwanted movement). Heck, I can almost FPS-game on a touchpad - it's so embedded in muscle memory. Thankfully, it's come back with the Dell Latitude 7480 laptop (top of my wishlist), but I can't believe Lenovo made this deal-breaking mistake on the Anniversary Edition - the one thing that made a ThinkPad for me.

text: I think Louis Rossmann gave a better preview of this machine. It may be a throwback, but its lamentable lack of options with a very lacklustre CPU make this machine more of a novelty if you ask me. Also, the keyboard is a severe point of contention among present Lenovo customers who have demanded that very keyboard be put into their other lines of products. For years Lenovo have said it could not be done with backlighting, so they chose to pitch it and redesign a staple of the ThinkPad design which kept customers coming back to the line over the years. Now, the 25th Anniversary edition comes to town, and what does Lenovo include? Nothing but that same keyboard with backlighting that they claimed was impossible to deliver on models in the past! You have no options for different displays as even the old IBM model you reference did, and you are stuck with a touchscreen even if you rarely or never use it, and let us not forget the only graphics option that ships with the unit, a middle of the road dedicated GPU on a laptop that is supposed to marketed to people who need a laptop that will last for some amount of years and is built for specific tasks like CAD, 3D modeling, etc. This was a nice homage by Lenovo, but it should have come with options, been priced much more competitively, limited run notwithstanding, and the few endearing features from Lenovo should have been made available in models they were already selling four and five years ago.

text: The 1050 was released over a year ago. There's no excuse for a 940 being in this machine, especially for the price. Also I'm sorry but carrying (and paying for) an extra battery doesn't count as great battery life (you literally need 2 of them to make it comparable...). Don't get me wrong; it's a nice option that I've missed, but when you look at the battery life on a single pack (and with a 1080p panel??) it's not that fantastic. Good, but not fantastic. On that note, for $1900 why isn't there at least a 1440p panel? This is by no means an ultra light, so there isn't an excuse for all these misgivings. You also have to remember that even with strong build quality there's still a lot of plastic in it's construction. It's just not a good deal for the price. I love the comparison bit Linus is doing with the OG ThinkPad, but I dislike the lack of proper criticism, especially when he's telling you you should buy one! Love this channel, but I don't like this video :(

text:
The feel of using a ThinkPad is difficult to describe. It does make other consumer grade laptops feel like toys. They really inspire confidence and aid you where you need it (the nipple, keyboard, reliability) but otherwise stay out of your way so you feel like you can get on with your job. They feel like a luxury sedan - dependable, stylish in a business type way, comfortable, safe and have enough performance to get the job done comfortably. I really can't recommend business grade machines enough for non-gaming use - forget about consumer grade garbage.

I particularly enjoy running Linux on ThinkPads. Many core Linux (and Driver) developers use ThinkPads so their drivers and whatever tend to be very well developed and maintained.

Full disclosure: I use refurbished Dell Latitudes rather than ThinkPads these days as I feel the specs at the $350 price point are often better and the experience is comparable. One of these usually lasts me 18 months or so because I don't feel bad about just chucking it in a backpack rather than being particularly gentle.

author: Rob Bannister

text:
Lenovo has lost the plot with the ThinkPad series over the last few years. It all started with the new keyboard on the Tx30 series, but I could get used to that one. Then the lid latch and ThinkLight disappeared. Then it seems they started targeting Apple users. This newfangled "Anniversary" macho cow stool even has a misplaced lid hinge, no optical drive and somehow they even forgot VGA. It's not a tribute to the classic ThinkPad and their users, it's giving them the third finger twice while laughing from all the money hipsters will happily fling towards anything old looking.

Lenovo needs to understand that ThinkPads got their former reputation from being as reliable and versatile in a buisness environment as a swiss army knife in, well, the swiss army. Users that understand how downtime occurs and why it is expensive. Until that happens I'll hold on to my T530.

author: Lapine2

text:
For perspective, my parents are programmers. My father owned a 2002 Thinkpad. They are the type to own this laptop.

I asked my mother, in regards to this laptop, if she'd rather have a wider screen for programming, or taller.

The answer is taller, so you can see more lines at once.

Compiling also takes a while, which is CPU intensive and benefits greatly from multiple cores when compiling several files at once.

Louis Rossman talked about it in terms of video editing/production which brought it to my attention, but the same applies to programming.

To understand just how terrible of a value this laptop is, I'd like you to consider the Asus laptop with an R7 1700. It costs 200 dollars less than this, with more processing and graphics.

Lenovo is trying to be Retro for styling sake, ignoring the basic principles of computer hardware in order to create an expensive laptop, so they can get people to shut up and stop complaining about their changes. If they want the old styling, well, you can get it at a massive price premium compared to much better laptops that cost hundreds of dollars cheaper. So, you can't complain, but you don't but the old design either.

text: Tong Zou, Louis disliked the laptop because, besides the keyboard, it did nothing to promote "retro."  There was no ThinkLight, no display latch, (as you mentioned) no 4:3 display, and (as Linus mentioned) no brightness slider.  People like Louis and I don't just care about the keyboard; in his opinion (see his video on the keyboard and TrackPoint) and mine, the new chiclet keyboards are just as good as the old.  However, "real ThinkPad users," the enthusiasts and fans who will actually buy this, are people who want usability and function (over form) for them instead of fancy, special packaging.  I do a lot of programming, and a 4:3 display, like the old ThinkPads, make a very noticeable difference in productivity; ThinkPads weren't made for media consumption, they were made (not as much so now) to be the best for work tasks, like programming.  Also the CPU and GPU are both too weak; most "real ThinkPad users" need workstation-level power (like the P series), not a dual-core CPU and a GPU that can't do more than basic acceleration.  Also, as Louis points out, the 1080p screen, while good enough for most people, is very outdated as of today.  And the problem with all of this is that there are no options; you can't get a quad-core CPU and more powerful GPU if you wanted, you can't get a good screen, and you can't get more than one retro feature.  And many people (including myself) would be willing to pay several hundreds of dollars more for these upgrades.  Poor specs plus poor implementation of retro (basically just a T570 with a different keyboard) equals a failed product for real ThinkPad users and enthusiasts.  (And, yes, the T470 and T470p are great laptops, but they are for a completely different market of people than the Retro; they are for mainstream business users, not enthusiasts and fans of the brand who will be looking for a Retro.)
author: Christopher Dix

text: People are angry because Lenovo marketed this as 'retro' which they shouldn't have. This is a modern laptop with a different keyboard. its not retro in any way. Its a one off. 4:3 display is impossible to source. lid is too thin for the ThinkLight. they reused existing motherboard due to it being a one off model.
author: Tong Zou

text: The only 14" laptop with a more powerful CPU is the heavier T470p. And that has the same GPU as the TP25. There is no 14" business laptop with a better GPU at the moment. (no XPS is not a business laptop, look at the Latitude line). And when has the Thinkpad had a great screen? Go look at your venerated T61 again and tell me again look past the 4:3 aspect ratio and thats when you realize its a crappy TFT screen with CCFL backlighting. Also this is not advertised as a workstation (a la the P series) Lets look at the specs again, now compare the ports keyboard removable battery and wwan options to other similarly priced notebooks like the Macbook Pro with the stupid gimmicky touch bar and no ports and a shit keyboard or the MS Surfacebook 2 which costs $500 more and tell me again how this is overpriced.
author: Tong Zou

text: Exactly!  (I was criticizing it that way because that's what their marketing said (therefore targeting a different audience than other models); regardless of marketing, it's a great mainstream business machine.)
author: Christopher Dix

text: At this time, that's true; I'm looking forward to seeing what Lenovo has to offer with the 8th Gen quad cores at CES next week.  My complaint with the GPU is that they could have used the GeForce MX150, much more powerful (the Pascal replacement of the 940MX) with the same TDP.  My hope is that they can get a Max-Q GTX 1050 in this class machine; the only system out now that achieves this (I wish a ThinkPad Yoga will come out with a model with similar specs) is the Acer Nitro 5 Spin (not a business laptop).  (And, yes, XPS wasn't designed for business)

text: As a current ThinkPad user who uses his ThinkPad primarily for 3D CAD design on Solidworks, the pointing stick is very well suited to panning and rotating around your model in 3D space. text:
soapsmellsgood
First of if i admit I'm dumb doesn't that defeat your argument since I'm dumb and I'm perfectly capable of using Linux every day of the week without a problem. For a smart fellow like you it should be easy then!

But on a serious note:

do you think macOS is hard to learn? Was your first experience with a smartphone OS the worst day of your life? Linux is different to Windows for sure but it's not at all hard to use.

Your confusing the difficulty of learning Linux with your of lack interest in doing so.

There are may beginner distributions like Elementary OS, Ubuntu, Linux mint among others that will help you with all the tools to maintain your system and do day to day tasks.
"Linux is hard to use" is a cop out, just say you have no interest in doing so and all Linux folks
will go "That's fine have a nice day".

What your doing is telling folks "It's hard to use" making potential new users to scared to try it and we Linux folks don't like that.
author: wil7vin

text:
Crispened Ham
Most Linux distributions have GUI package managers bundled now so no need to jump in Terminal if you don't want to. Their are a lot of noob friendly distributions out their that can get a new users feet wet in the world of Linux most of them have low maintenance and great driver support.

How you install packages is indeed different but I find that's one of the reasons it's easier to use!
You have to get used to the package manager (but they have gui's now so it's not that hard) but once you do you can update every program on your system ALL of it no need to go to your browser to download the latest version of Firefox all your programs are updated in one click or command which greatly increases security for a non tech user who would never update their software otherwise.

On the install thing yes it's a thing you have to do but a five year old can install Linux it's really not hard.
Not only that but even if you really don't know how to set it up and a tech friend does it for you that tech friend can rest assured it won't have to be reinstalled every 6 months like a Windows install in the hands of a non technical user.

A friend of mine switched his non technical mom over to Linux and she doesn't even notice that her computer is 'Different' she just emails and browses the net like any non tech user does.
author: wil7vin

text:
Crispend Ham
Why would you need to use curl or wget to download something? You do know firefox has a 'Save as' button on most links? You say you have to know the apps name do the apt-get command yeah you do
but you also know their is a apt-cache command to search the repos for you?

Not only that but the GUI for the package manager on ubuntu has a search feature build right in.

text: when I was a kid my mom had an old Thinkpad, but it was at LEAST a generation or two newer than that one.  1024x768 TN screen, 128mb ram, a better GPU not sure exactly what it was... maybe a tnt 2 that i THINK had dedicated memory but I'm not positive... a bigger HD, and a 466mhz celeron... yes unfortunately she skimped on the cpu and it was a cellery and not a real pentium, that would have been much better.  but it was still pretty good for back then, and much better than the one linus picked up.  it could at least run windows 98 just fine, and play games like Unreal Tournament and Quake 3, half life, NFS2 / hot pursuit, c&c red alert 2 / tiberian sun, and of course worms armageddon.  i liked the stick, although it wasn't ideal for gaming, but for an FPS it was actually better than a track pad.  for a game like worms or c&c it is inferior to a track pad.  no slider for brightness on her model either.  battery life was not great... I don't think i could ever get 2 full length movies out of it.  but at some tasks, the 466 celeron was faster than our desktop 350mhz k6-2 before I figured out how to turn on the "turbo" overclocking feature, but the gpu was inferior to the 16mb (i think) voodoo 2 we had.

text:
When i bought a ThinkPad about 3 years ago, it came with a defective keyboard. It took them 3 months on a repair center to get a spare keyboard. And when it came back from the repair center, the keyboard was still defective.

A similar thing happened to one of my co-workers last year. He got a brand new ThinkPad and it came with a defective screen. It took them about a month to two months for them to fix it.

Just google the horrors of Lenovo support, I personally wouldn't buy a computer from them. Not to mention they use proprietary parts, meaning that it becomes more difficult if you want to get a replacement part to repair your laptop.

text: He's right about this one though. The problem is not just with this thinkpad in particular, but how Lenovo handled the problems the users had with modern thinkpads. Releasing one overpriced laptop with a 16:9 screen is only going to piss more people off (instead of releasing a whole line of "classic" thinkpads for example).
author: feketekocka

text: first off, its not overpriced. price a T470 to the same specs and see what you get. Note that the T470 can not get dedicated graphics like the TP25 can. Also note: how many 14" business laptops have dedicated graphics anyways? Another is the retro stuff, this was all explained by Lenovo in their unboxing video: the ThinkLight is not there because the lid is too thin to add it. The display is not 16:10 or 4:3 because it would have to be custom made in large numbers to be financially feasible and this is a limited run laptop. So basically this is a T470 with dedicated graphics and an upgraded keyboard, thats it. its not retro in any way. but is that a bad thing? not necessarily. I think its still a much better buy than the macbook pro which sells for similar price, has a gimmicky touch bar, 90% less ports, non removable battery and shitty keyboard. If Louis Rossman has so many problems with it he can go create his own retro thinkpad then

text: I have a Thinkpad T530, modded with a T520 classic keyboard, and even though it's over 4 years old, it's still amazing. After the last time I opened it to switch the CPU to an i7 Quadcore (which makes it almost as fast as the 25th anniversary model)  I apparently forgot to connect the trackpad and I just noticed it a few days later because I exclusively use the trackpoint. Having a trackpoint is so much more convenient even compared to a modern precision trackpad. The most used function keys like the ones for brightness, are positioned logically which makes them easy to hit without even looking and having dedicated volume and mute keys is just one more thing I miss on modern Notebooks.

author: Jeremy Stock

text:
This thing is not good. It is got no inspiration from any real thinkpads at all.
It has those hinges that rotate in the body, so the screen will cover the back of the system, so you can't get to ports there, no ventilation will work there, you can't have the nice bar at the bottom that shows the model name or indicator lights, WHICH THIS THING HAS NO INDICATOR LIGHTS AT ALL. *YOU CAN'T EVEN TELL IF YOU HAVE THE NUMBER LOCK ON FFS*. -(I could rant about the lack of indicator lights alone, no power light, no pluged in light, no battery indicator, no hdd activity, no network activity, no bluetooth power, no nothing) There is no latches holding it together, the build of the system is awful, it has none of the 'rollcage' chassis (look at the whole thing f**king bend when linus pushes on it) no liquid holes, no expansion doors, almost impossible to open and service inside, the body design is rubbish and cheap with that minimalist design all over it, there are very minimal ports, no ultra bay, no edges on the oversized touchpad, no mouse buttons on the touchpad (???), no edges to the touch pad. 
It's just... crap.
All lenovo have done here is got one of their older and most popular keyboards, and glued it to one of their rubbishy modern thinkpads and called it a day. You can really tell the extreme lack of quality when there's a thinklight button, and no thinklight on the laptop. It's all of the unnecessary problems and compromises of modern laptops, for a ridiculous price point.
Do not purchase this. If you are looking for real thinkpad quality, look on a used market for something like a T61 for ¬£20 or a T420 for a little more if you need more modern specs.

author: RUNDEN

text: Hard to service?  Most of them you loosen 8 screws and the entire bottom pops off.  Most of the ultrabooks they make and T series laptops are this way.  What Thinkpads have you worked on?  If you mean some Ideapad garbage that doesnt count. Also, there's an OSD that tells you when numlock/capslock is on.  I dont really see a problem with that because why would you want to know/care if the numlock was on when the computer wasnt on?
author: autotalon

text:
I work on mostly T410 - T430, and X200 series. On these, ONE SCREW is all you need to remove the ram door, and open the keyboard, letting you get to all of the main parts you would need to for most services. I understand more screws isn't harder, but in places, they use less screws and replace them with these plastic click tabs, it is not very nice clicking off the palmrest that is in one piece (it used to come in two seperate pieces, much nicer when taking off), sometimes accidentally snapping off the little plastic parts. This is really bad in the screens too, normally I have to get off the little rubbery cover and unscrew it, now there is just snap into place plastic only, which I need a special tool thing that fits in the gap, which gets more broken each use, and I need to be cautions of not putting pressure on the screen and in the end, I usually end up ordering a new screen bezel, because the first one snaps or all of the little tabs on one side have snapped off. I understand I am not the most steady hand at removing these, but it really should be easier than this !
I see that there is an OSD with the number lock and caps lock, but it fades away a few seconds after you enable/disable, and these OSD I really have trouble getting to work properly again after installing annother windows installation, and for linux users (which is large on thinkpad market), they do not get any option at all. The need for number lock light is that the number lock keys overwrite the keyboard keys, I can see problems happening where a user accidentally enables the number lock or leaves on, and then mistypes as it is left on, and for not the most knowing of the users, can get very confused of why this is happening on the keyboard, as they cannot see that the number lock is on. I do not see what you mean by the 'why would you want to know if numlock was on when the computer wasnt on', lights like number lock are not powered when the computer is on, it is a visible to see if number lock is enabled or not, without something covering the screen or taking space in the system tray. Sorry if my english is not very good.

text: The IBM ThinkPad R50 back in 2003 had an amazing 2048x1536 IPS display. I bought a fully functioning 1400x1050 model for $25 a few months ago; on Lubuntu 17.10 it runs comparably to a cheap Windows 10 netbook, which isn't bad for the money. It can even get some work done still; sending a 12MP raw through RawTherapee, Krita, and NeatImage is very doable, despite the single-core Pentium M, as long as you don't go too fast. Plus it can hold two batteries, screen folds 180 degrees, and it has almost every legacy port you might need in field work.

text:
***This Laptop is shit btw***

"Not everyone is going to like a track point."
"It does take a little getting used to."
I appreciate you taking a look at this laptop, Linus; but as a long time Thinkpad user I have a few gripes with your video. Before I begin I will clarify that I am a computer hardware specialist in the military and use a Librebooted T400 as my daily use laptop and have a W520 with Windows 10 as a desktop replacement. Okay now I'll start. 
"-that would still hold up today?"
Your point of comparison is of a 20 year old laptop. Maybe I'm cherry-picking by saying this, but of 20+ year old hardware IBM would have the best stuff that even still performs. My T400 is now almost 10 years old, and it still has the classic keyboard which is the main point drawn by Thinkpad fanatics and collectors in terms of when they stopped being good- not if they were being made by IBM. In which case the best comparison would be with a T420 or W520. Now talking about specs, my T400 outspecs half the current Chromebook market. So yes, I'd say that these computers hold up. Now, this laptop specifically I'm not sure. It is barely an upgrade from my W520- mostly with innovation in size. This is also not a gaming laptop, but if you really wanted to you could. Esports titles like CS:GO will run on those specs if at ~720p and low setting with 60+ fps. I don't know. I'm probably getting upset at nothing right now.

author: television and cheese

text:
Really was hoping for a viable replacement for my T420, I'm definitely starting to feel the age of it (Sandy Bridge/2011 era). However, it still has superior design and features to any Thinkpad models since then. Was hoping they'd go back to the pinnacle of ThinkPads (T420/520 for me, there's some differences of opinion on that of course), and just take the best ThinkPad they made, review the weak points of it and improve those, and call it a day. Basically, a T420 with a better screen (better quality panel, better resolution, better aspect ratio; the T420 screen sucked in every way)... and that's it. T420 with a better screen, that's all that was needed to create an awesome (read: useful) ThinkPad. (And, obviously, the obligatory update to internals and I/O). Instead we get the same thing as their modern ThinkPads, but with a different keyboard. Which is great, but it's not nearly enough to make it a replacement for an actual ThinkPad. So... Still waiting for a replacement. Might just swap mine for a T520 just so I can get a better screen and quad core in the meantime...

Lenovo markets the whole retro ThinkPad thing as a collectible memorial piece, they seem to have misunderstood completely. I have work to do. The people who want a ThinkPad with some of the older design decisions aren't asking for it out of sentiment. We don't want it because it's old, we just want whatever is better for getting our stuff done. It just so happens that their older designs are better for getting work done than their newer designs, so we want the older ones, but the fact that they're older is basically just happenstance, it has nothing to do with why we want them to design a laptop in that way. Sadly, beyond the keyboard, not much of the old design decisions have been re-implemented, and to top it off the specs are pathetic for the price. I'm kinda surprised Linus didn't rip it to shreds considering it's $1,900 for a dual-core, 940 MX, 1080p machine in 2017. I mean... good lord.

Anyway, so I'm still waiting for a successor to my 2011 model.

text:
When my Lenovo T61p died of old age in 2017, I jumped on ebay and picked up a Lenovo x220 for ¬£50, sold as faulty (A bit of tape to cover the Thinkpoint PCB under the keyboard stopped it shorting on the mobo and it was fixed! Scoop!).
Now it's a monster with 16GB 1866MHz, 1TB Samsung 850 EVO SSD and a 1050 ti plugged into a PE4C 3.0 Expresscard PCIe adapter which runs a 144Hz 1080p AOC panel. 

And after all that, I put the T61p mobo in the oven for 8 minutes at 180c' and it came back to life!

And that's my exciting Thinkpad story, thanks for listening.

text: I have owned a Lenovo Thinkpad Yoga 460 for about half a year now, and like the rest of the thinkpads, it is no gaming machine, but as a productivity workhorse, it has always been the brand to go for. I got mine to use as a school laptop. The stylus is incredibly useful for diagrams/written notes, the build quality is remarkable, it has a good array of I/O, the fingerprint reader is a huge time-saver, and the battery life is solid, and the keyboard is amazing to type on. It also has the trackpoint, which I actually find myself missing when I use other laptops, and the way that the keyboard border raises up when flipping the screen into tablet mode is a super-smart idea that I wish was implemented on other 2-in-1s, as it makes it easier to hold without needing to worry about damaging the keys, and when the keyboard border is up, rubber feet also raise up around the keyboard to hold it above the surface you place the laptop on (in stand or tablet mode) to prevent the keyboard from picking up crumbs and dirt from the table. It is  a brilliantly designed device and I wish more devices had  these sort of features. My favourite thing, however, is that they are super-cheap on ebay, some even brand new. Some sell as low as ¬£200-400 if you get your bid in at the right time :)

text: It's a piece of crap because Lenovo literally retrofitted one of their last-gen laptops with the classic keyboard instead of bothering to build a true Classic ThinkPad from the ground up. So aside from the keyboard, it has literally nothing differentiating it from a current ThinkPad (no 4:3 or 8:5 display), and it uses last-gen specs (dual-core CPU and GeForce 940MX instead of quad-core CPU and MX150). So basically, we're getting neither a classic ThinkPad design nor current-gen specs.

text: +Matthew Bauer ThinkPads NEVER where about the Design, at least the T and X Series. They where practical and the rest came behind that. That's what made them special. ThinkPads right now are nothing special. You get better stuff elsewhere. I still love my X201, but time has taken it's toll on the old Westmere and the Screen. Unfortunately it's rocking the 1440x900 (the "4k" back in the day) which are extremely hard to find. Nevertheless: ThinkPads nowadays are crapboxes, so are EliteBooks. Everything has to look good and needs to be light as f**k. No, it doesn't! The old HP Elitebooks, like the 8470w were built like tanks. They could survive drops from the table all day, they could be upgraded, the fan could be changed in a matter of minutes - even the old Thinkpads were good in that regard-, and they didn't overheat nor throttle when you pushed them all day long. Now you have to rip out the whole motherboard to even get to the freaking fan! The sad part is: They could be built lighter and a bit like ultrabooks but nooo - that's to expensive and will hurt the shareholders income...man, i do hate disposable society - sorry. Rant over. Dont buy ThinkPads.
author: Nexusband

text:
Every year they release a dozen models that are new laptops from the ground up. It's not going to be any more expensive than any other laptop, barring some price increases for a made-to-order screen if the aspect ratio they want isn't already being manufactured, which is no excuse. Even Apple can make a machine with decent specs and a made-to-order screen at $1300, it's nonsense to say making a new ThinkPad, which they do every year anyway, but just pull design decisions that they made further in the past instead of design decisions from more recently in the past, and a made-to-order screen, would make it cost beyond what anyone would pay.

The problem is the whole limited edition thing, the price is high because they aren't going to sell many units, so the development cost isn't spread out among lots of sales. If they hadn't gone with the whole "collectors edition" mentality and just realized people want a laptop to do work on, and approached it from a large scale main channel sale perspective, it could have come out a lot better and a lot cheaper. But they missed the point of why people asked for the project in the first place.

text:
So my X220 that after many drops, wet fields and general banging around, that has so far only suffered a slightly wobbly left screen hinge and a chipped bit of plastic in the left corner of the keyboard, isn't durable?
Or my E540, that whilst at the cheap end of the range (for thinkpads anyway) is still holding together perfectly after 3 years (save for one dead pixel at the very bottom of the screen).
Both easy to take apart, both have the fantastic nipple mouse, and they put other laptop keyboards to shame.
I know people with X210's, a T430, and a T460. They love them too.
